Award.AwardTitle: An Improved Accounting: Searching for Faint Dwarf Galaxies Beyond the Local Group
Award.AbstractNarration:
Faint dwarf galaxies are the building blocks of large galaxies, and are hypothesized to be the most abundant galaxies in the Universe. Because of their low mass (thus, low gravitational binding energies), they are the most susceptible to any process that removes or prevents gas from condensing to form stars. However, because they are so dim, the only well-studied sample of faint dwarfs consists of those in the Local Group of Galaxies that includes our own Milky Way galaxy. This project expects to answer some of the open questions about faint dwarf galaxies using deep imaging data: How abundant are they in the local Universe? What is the relation between the mass of their stars and their halos of invisible "dark matter"? Which processes terminate star formation in faint dwarf galaxies? The researchers will also leverage dwarf galaxy searches as a way to increase student access to STEM careers. They will develop a dwarf-galaxy-hunting project for gifted high-school students attending the Ohio Supercomputer Center's annual two-week Summer Institute, and increase access to the program including through scholarships to be funded via this project. The team will produce a "This Is How We Science" video blog (vlog). This vlog will follow the researchers through the milestones and daily tasks associated with the project, and will also feature a how-to guide for young students interested in scientific careers.

The project will take a census of faint dwarf galaxies in the nearby Universe using existing deep, multi-wavelength Large Binocular Telescope imaging data from a "failed supernova" survey led by the Co-PI. The 21 host galaxies span the range of galaxy types expected to host most of the faint dwarfs in the local Universe. Analytic, semi-analytic, and numerical tools will be used to infer the relationship between the stellar masses of the faint dwarfs and their dark-matter halos, and to infer the faint dwarf number density in the local Universe. These models will also be used to investigate the relative strength of environmental, internal, and global quenching of star formation, as a function of host type and faint dwarf stellar mass.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Small galaxies sit at the intersection of many cosmic mysteries.  We think that the number of them per unit volume, as a function of size, tells us something about the nature of dark matter.  Because these galaxies are fragile, they may be more strongly affected by different processes that influence how they form stars and how they evolve than are larger galaxies.  To test the nature of dark matter and the processes that shape small galaxies, we need a well-understood census of small galaxies in a variety of environments, and a theoretical framework to connect observations to theory.

With this award, our diverse group of physicists and astronomers found and studied small galaxies around a diverse set of nearby galaxies, mainly through our Large Binocular Telescope Satellites of Nearby Galaxies (LBT-SONG) survey.  With LBT-SONG, we focus on small galaxies very close to their much larger "host" galaxies, a regime that has not been well studied in the literature, and which provides us a long lever arm on interactions between small galaxies and their hosts.
Through a combination of observations and a powerful yet simple new theoretical framework, we find that the number of small galaxies near the larger ones is consistent with standard dark matter and galaxy evolution theory.  We have strong indirect evidence that small galaxies lose their gas and stop forming stars in part due to the tenuous halo of gas surrounding the "host" galaxies that the small galaxies orbit.  Although this is expected for larger host galaxies, it is unexpected for the set of our hosts that are as small as the Large Magellanic Cloud.  In addition to these key science results, the theoretical and observational analysis tools we developed in this project will an important role in interpreting future wide-field galaxy survey data.

We reach the broader community through two types of project., with the goal of making astronomy and physics more accessible to more people, especially high school students.  First, we developed image processing and galaxy search projects for high school students attending the Ohio Supercomputer Center Summer Institute and the Ohio State University Achieving in Science through Physics Instrumentation, Research, and Exploration (ASPIRE) summer camps, and worked with students throughout the camps.  ASPIRE is specifically for women, who are represented in this field.  Second, we run the social media campaign "How We Science" to show how we do our science, and show who we are as scientists.
